{{Infobox musical artist | name = Willie D. Warren | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1924|9|11|mf=y}}
[[Stamps, Arkansas|Stamps]], [[Arkansas]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|2000|12|30|1924|9|11|mf=y}}
[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], United States | origin = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Detroit blues]], [[electric blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[double bass|bassist]], [[singing|singer]] | years_active = 1940s–2000 | label = | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Willie D. Warren''' (September 11, 1924 – December 30, 2000){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2000.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2000 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-01}} was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[guitarist]], [[double bass|bass player]] and [[singing|singer]]. In a long career, he worked with [[Otis Rush]], [[Al Benson]], Little Sonny Cooper, [[David Honeyboy Edwards]], [[Baby Boy Warren]], [[Guitar Slim]], [[Freddie King]], [[Jimmy Reed]], Morris Pejoe, [[Bobo Jenkins]] and [[Jim McCarty (guitarist)|Jim McCarty]]. One of Warren's better known [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] was "Baby Likes to Boogie". He was described by [[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Michael G. Nastos, as "one of the Midwest's true blues treasures". ==Biography== Warren was born in [[Stamps, Arkansas|Stamps]], [[Arkansas]], but moved with his family at the age of thirteen to [[Lake Village, Arkansas]]. He was taught by [[Caleb King]] to play the [[guitar]], and played in his own blues ensemble around the [[Mississippi Delta]]. His band's singer, [[Guitar Slim]] was, in turn, taught guitar playing techniques by Warren, and they toured around [[Louisiana]] in the latter half of the 1940s. Warren relocated to [[Chicago]] by the early 1950s and joined [[Otis Rush]]'s band. He later played alongside [[Freddie King]] and [[Jimmy Reed]], plus he also backed Morris Pejoe, when Pejoe recorded tracks for [[Chess Records]]. Warren formed the House Rockers back in Arkansas in 1959, and by the early 1970s had moved to [[Detroit]] to work and record with [[Bobo Jenkins]]. From 1974 to 1976 he was also a featured performer, along with [[Baby Boy Warren]] (no relation), with the Progressive Blues Band, a popular blues band that played in many of Detroit's best blues venues. When Baby Boy died in 1977, Wille D. Warren took up the band's [[frontman]] duties.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=willie-d-warren-p391268/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Willie D. Warren |author=Reif, Fred |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 14, 2010}} In 1977, Warren finally recorded his debut solo album, which was released on Jenkins' Big Star [[record label|label]]. In addition, Warren turned [[songwriter]], penning the lyrics to two songs ("Door Lock Blues" and "Detroit Jump") that Jenkins himself recorded for his own ''Detroit All Purpose Blues'' album.{{cite web |url=http://www.detroitmusichistory.com/BoBo.html |title=Bobo Jenkins - a bluesman's journey|author=Reif, Fred |publisher=Detroitmusichistory.com |accessdate=October 14, 2010}} Warren's own work then appeared on a small number of [[compilation album]]s. His [[live album]], ''Live'', for the No Cover Productions label, was not released until after Warren's death. His then backing band, Mystery Train, included his old friend [[Jim McCarty (guitarist)|Jim McCarty]]. Warren died in Detroit, in December 2000, at the age of 76. He left one son, Willie Hairston. The Detroit Blues Society posthumously recognized Warren's contribution to the blues with their 2011 Lifetime Achievement Award.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailytribune.com/articles/2011/01/20/entertainment/doc4d38586393e38238689474.txt |title=Blues musicians Bobby Murray, Willie D. Warren honored |author=Ballor, Joe |date=January 20, 2011 |work= |publisher=Dailytribune.com |accessdate=December 20, 2011}} ==Partial discography== ===Albums=== *''Live'' (2005) - Willie D. Warren & Mystery Train - No Cover Productions{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/live-mw0000505719 |title=Live - Willie D. Warren | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2005-04-11 |accessdate=2014-02-01}} ===Compilation albums=== *''Hastings Street Grease Vol. 1'' (1998) - Blue Suit Records *''Hastings Street Grease Vol. 2'' (1999) - Blue Suit Records{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/burnsfrm.htm |title=Eddie and Jimmy Burns discography |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ==See also== *[[List of Detroit blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.backstagegallery.com/artist/WillieDWarrenMysteryTrain.html?size=large&sort=year-desc&photographer=&page=4 Warren & Mystery Train photographs at Backstagegallery.com] {{Authority control|VIAF=71080690}} {{Persondata | NAME =Warren, Willie D | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[guitarist]], [[double bass|bass player]] and singer | DATE OF BIRTH =September 11, 1924 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Stamps, Arkansas]], United States | DATE OF DEATH =December 30, 2000 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Warren, Willie D}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Arkansas]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Detroit blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Arkansas]]
